cmCourseInfo.description: What is Catholicism, as an idea, as a social movement, as an object of scorn, devotion or delight? What meaning does Catholic tradition have in the contemporary world? This seminar explores these and similar questions through lectures and conversations with diverse scholars—faculty, fellows and friends—of the St. Michael’s College community.
cmCourseInfo.title: Catholicism in Conversation

This course will employ both synchronous and asynchronous learning components. Participation in synchronous online class sessions (lectures and some tutorials) will be required, but recordings of synchronous lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously.

courses.name: SMC One: The McLuhan Seminar in Creativity and Technology

notes.name: Section Note

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar is an interdisciplinary exploration of the relationship between creativity and technology. Inspired by the innovative thinking of Marshall McLuhan, it explores how the humanities relate to other fields of thought and research in addressing the individual, social and cultural experiences and effects of technological innovation. This course includes a mandatory travel component opportunity to Silicon Valley, California. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. (An ancillary fee of $1,000 is required to help cover some of the travel costs.)
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The McLuhan Seminar in Creativity and Technology
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC165H1, SMC188H1, SMC189H1

courses.name: SMC One: The Boyle Seminar in Scripts and Stories

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar introduces students to university-level studies through an interdisciplinary exploration of Celtic influences in the mediaeval world, with a particular focus on early books and historical artifacts as physical objects and bearers of meaning. Students will learn how to read and analyse these books and artifacts to decode their meanings, and, in support of that, take introductory language instruction in Latin or Irish. Subjects discussed will include intercultural encounter and dialogue, research methods with historical sources, and the relationship between the written word and lived experience, then and now. There is a co-curricular travel opportunity to Dublin, Ireland associated with this course which takes place following the Winter term exam period. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. (If you choose to go on the trip to Ireland, an ancillary fee of $1,000 is required to help cover some of the travel costs.)
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The Boyle Seminar in Scripts and Stories
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC155H1, SMC188H1, SMC189H1

Delivery Instructions

From a variety of perspectives, the seminar considers how religion, and how different kinds of religious experience, figure in the broader context of human affairs. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an intensive international learning experience in Rome, Italy. It offers contemporary and historical models of integrating faith with reason, and religious practice with intellectual, creative, and public engagement, specifically the roles that the Catholic Church and Vatican play in Rome, in ecology, science, literature, and public life. This course includes a mandatory travel component to Rome, Italy, which takes place following the Winter term exam period. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. (An ancillary fee of $2,000 is required to help cover some of the travel costs.)
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The Gilson Seminar in Faith and Rome

courses.name: God and Money in the Middle Ages

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar considers the ethical, political, and spiritual questions arising from the existence of wealth and poverty in medieval European culture. With readings from Dante, Chaucer, Thomas Aquinas and others, the course will examine how the interaction of spiritual ideals and material realities shaped cultural developments from late antiquity to the Protestant Reformation. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: God and Money in the Middle Ages

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to watch a short pre-recorded lecture before class and then attend a live tutorial-style discussion during the scheduled class time.

courses.name: The Sistine Chapel: History, Imagery, Usage

cmCourseInfo.description: The Sistine Chapel in Rome is a historical artifact, an artistic monument, and a house of worship—at once recognizable and mystifying. This seminar explores fifteenth-century origins, decoration by some of the most accomplished artists of the Italian renaissance, and continuing use (especially the election of popes). Topics will include: art and patronage, rhetoric and ritual, controversial restoration, and the Sistine Chapel in popular culture—with an emphasis on the close analysis of the major frescoes. The seminar will develop the academic skills needed for the analysis and discussion of texts, paintings, and ritual events. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Sistine Chapel: History, Imagery, Usage

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 20, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Games and play are a fundamental part of human society, and today digital games occupy a central place in popular culture, media industries, and the imaginations of players around the world. This seminar introduces students to the growing academic field of game studies, with an emphasis on close analysis of specific games as cultural objects. Through lectures, discussions, and in-class play sessions, students will build a critical vocabulary and toolbox of techniques for understanding the unique formal, aesthetic, narrative, and thematic properties of games in a variety of platforms and genres, and develop basic academic reading, writing, and research skills. No previous experience or expertise with video games is required to take this course. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: How to Study Video Games

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access all essential course content online and asynchronously (i.e. watching recordings, reading, and making contributions to discussions on their own schedule). Some parts of the course will also optionally be available online synchronously (i.e. livestreamed in real time) Tuesdays 10-1. Office hours and other optional meetings or activities may be occasionally offered in person if possible.

cmCourseInfo.description: What is human intelligence? How close are we to replicating it? How productive/reductive is the brain-computer analogy? What ethical challenges are posed by AI on workers, society, and the environment? Can we put a hold on "progress"? Is Silicon Valley the seat of a new techno-religion? What can they teach us about today's research priorities? What insight (or inspiration) can we get from works of science fiction about the future of human-AI interaction? Through reading discussion, written assignment, and workshops, this seminar will present students with the opportunity to integrate their computer science interests with philosophy, history, and literature. There is an equivalent course offered by the Department of Computer Science. Students may take one or the other but not both. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intelligence, Artificial and Human

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Seminar sessions will not be recorded and are strictly synchronous affairs. Opportunities will be provided to remote participants for interacting with the in-class participants, but will require the software packages Zoom and Discord.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to creative works from throughout the global Christian tradition. The course explores the complex relationships that exist between religious and aesthetic imperatives, between theological and material sources, between beauty and suffering, and between artists and their patrons and audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and the Arts

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Christianity and Society Through the Ages

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the historical engagement of various Christian traditions with the prevailing political, social, and ethnic cultures in the western world and beyond. Students will also examine the development of Christianity as it confronts changes in the symbolic and intellectual universes from antiquity to post-modernity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Society Through the Ages

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the thought and culture of early mediaeval Europe. Students are introduced to important monuments of early mediaeval History, Thought, Literature, and Art. They follow some of the common threads that run through these disciplines and explore chief expressions of early mediaeval life and thought.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Early Mediaeval Tradition

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: The Middle Ages and the Movies

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the ways mediaeval themes have been presented in the cinema over the last century by taking exemplary films from different countries and epochs. The purpose is to explore each on three levels: the mediaeval reality, the subsequent legendary or literary elaboration, and the twentieth-century film rendition, regarded equally as work of art, ideology and economic product.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Middle Ages and the Movies

Students are introduced to important monuments of later mediaeval History, Thought, Literature, and Art. They follow some of the common threads that run through these disciplines and explore chief expressions of later mediaeval life and thought.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of pedagogy and child development theory, with a particular focus on the way Christians have employed these educational techniques historically. Attention will be given to the diversity of institutions and approaches to curriculum development across Christian history.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Education

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

SMC219Y is an online, synchronous course. Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students are expected to attend online lectures and participate in active learning activities. Lectures will be also recorded and shared on Quercus for students to review on their own time. Slides and other learning materials, such as weekly readings and case studies will be posted on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Zoom for all online sessions and Quercus for readings, assignments, and tests.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies a selection of Mediaeval Latin prose and poetry. Emphasis is on the linguistic differences between Mediaeval Latin and its classical antecedent, especially in regard to vocabulary, grammar and orthography. A review of Latin grammar is part of the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Latin Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Tuesdays 13:00-15:00 are required lectures, live-streamed or held in-person if possible. The remaining 2 hours of class time will be a combination of asynchronous lectures and exercises available on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the Arthurian legends from the earliest Latin histories through selected Welsh, French and German Romances to the English-language classic, Morte d’Arthur of Malory. Emphasis will be on reading the primary sources (in translation).
cmCourseInfo.title: King Arthur
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.
cmCourseInfo.title: Book History and Print Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. The 2 hours weekly lecture will be delivered live on Blackboard Collaborate 14:00-16:00 pm on Tuesdays with the opportunity for synchronous online discussion. Lectures will be recorded and available asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.
cmCourseInfo.title: Readers and Readerships

notes.name: Course Note

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously in combination with slides and other course materials. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via webinar are optional (and highly recommended) Tuesdays 2-4. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to provide for individual half-courses not already covered in the listed range of the Book and Media Studies Program offerings. Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

In 2013, The Black Lives Matter movement began with a hashtag to decry the acquittal of George Zimmerman following the shooting death of Black American teen Trayvon Martin. Since then, it has become a rallying call for Black people around the world and helped mobilize a generation against the injustices they endure. This course will explore the role of media in both the success and the hardships that Black Lives Matter activists have faced since the movement emerged. Do Black lives matter in the media? How has underrepresentation of Black people in mainstream media shaped movements for Black lives? Through the semester, we will seek to better understand how #BlackLivesMatter forged itself within, without, against and in spite of traditional media institutions, with a special focus on the Canadian context as well as an interest for the global movement beyond the United States.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed and delivered per the meeting schedule. Students require a high-speed internet connection. More details will be available in the syllabus.

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality) completed in Fall 2016; SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality and Transmedia) completed in Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The 2020 presidential election will be one of the most important in modern U.S. history, as the public decides whether to give President Donald Trump a second term after a first term marked by controversy and partisan dispute that has been reflected in and indeed intensified by media responses. The election, and the sharp conflict between and within the Republican and Democrat parties, and between their nominees for President, is sure to increase the pressures on political media and its role in reporting, interpreting, and even shaping events in a democracy of more than 300 million citizens. In this course, we will examine various aspects of the relationship between Trump and the Media across the full range of platforms – from legacy print media (books, magazines, newspapers) to cable TV and radio as well as Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Our goal is to gain a better understanding of Trump and Trumpism and of American media in the 21st century, in the context of the 2020 presidential election.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed and delivered per the meeting schedule. Students require Zoom and a high-speed Internet connection. Online discussion will take place during the lecture, and participation and attendance to the livestreamed lectures will be noted as part of the final evaluation of the course. Recordings of the lecture will be made available 24-48 hours after the scheduled meeting time; watching the lecture after the livestream will not count toward participation marks.

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality) completed in Fall 2016; SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality and Transmedia) completed in Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

One of the most significant developments in popular media since the late 1970s is the rise and proliferation of media franchises, which spread their commercial interests and fictional worlds across many multiple media. Reflective of the broader logics of media industry conglomeration and convergence, in media franchises movies, television series, novels and comics, games of all kinds, toys and merchandise, paratexts like promotional materials, etc. are linked together in order to maximize profits. These dense networks of commercial products serve as a platform for new forms of serial narrative and world-building such as "transmedia storytelling," and also generate vibrant, diverse fan cultures that extend far beyond the official franchise and its canonical texts. Drawing on a wide range of scholarly and critical work, this course examines the modern media franchise from historical, industrial, formal/aesthetic, and sociocultural perspectives. Media franchises to be examined include Marvel, Star Wars, DC, Harry Potter, The Matrix, and more. (This course was previously offered as SMC301 Seriality and Transmedia in 20181.)

Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access all essential course content online and asynchronously (i.e. watching recordings, completing readings, and making contributions to discussions on their own schedule). Some parts of the course will also optionally be available online synchronously (i.e. livestreamed in real time) Thursdays 10:00-1:00.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of both overt and covert representations of Christian ideas in contemporary popular media. We examine the ways in which Christian themes have been appropriated and subverted in mass media, while also examining the innovative ways these themes, such as redemption, sacrifice, vocation, and hope, are presented anew.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Popular Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This seminar will be delivered online. Students must be equipped with a microphone and a camera to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The Catholic Church claims to be the continuation of the event of Christ in history, the guarantor of the authenticity of each person's encounter with Christ, and the means by which His memory may be cultivated. The course examines the reasons for these claims and the forms they have taken.
cmCourseInfo.title: Why the Church

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: The Catholic Church has developed a distinctive approach to the pedagogical enterprise. This course explores aspects of this approach by an examination of canonical legislation and other texts published by ecclesiastical authorities and their application in Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Catholicism and Education

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: A deeper examination of key cases in the development of media, such as the invention of movable type, the mechanization of the printing press, standardization of call number systems (Dewey, LC, etc.), the advent of radio, television and internet. Topics vary from year to year, according to the instructor.

cmCourseInfo.description: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Technology and Networks

Some parts of the course will also optionally be available online synchronously (i.e. livestreamed in real time) Wednesdays 1-3pm. Office hours and other optional meetings or activities may be occasionally offered in person if possible.

cmCourseInfo.description: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.

An exploration of diverse media narratives to address cultural approaches to trauma.

Opportunities for class discussions via webinar (or in-person if conditions permit) are optional and are held on Mondays 10:00-12:00. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

notes.content: Oct 30, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a theoretical foundation that enables them to identify and analyze ethical issues in mainstream and non-mainstream media. Traditional principles of journalistic truth-seeking, objectivity, and minimizing harm are revisited in the light of global, interactive media, produced by both citizens and professionals.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of what Pope John Paul II, among others, called the "feminine tradition" in Christian life and thought. Possible topics include women's roles in the early church, Marian dogmas and devotions, women mystics and Doctors of the Church, and Christian feminisms and New Feminisms in the contemporary period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Christianity

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be held as scheduled in the timetable. It is required that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies selections from the rich variety of Mediaeval Latin poetry, rhymed as well as rhythmic, and provides a survey of prosody and metrics. A solid foundation in basic Latin morphology, syntax and vocabulary is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Latin Poetry

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Delivery will be synchronous, there will be no recording of the class, and students are expected to have computers with both cameras and microphones.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course looks at some of the major literary figures of Ireland in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, writing in both Irish and English. Authors examined may include W. B. Yeats, Patrick Pearse, Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill, Seán Ó Riordáin, Seamus Heaney and Claire Keegan. Through a close reading of poetry, prose and critical texts, students will examine how Ireland's past, present and future are variously figured in its greatest modern literature. All Irish-language works will be read in English translation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Ireland
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FCE or permission of the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 3, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the relationship between folklore and national identity in Ireland, Scotland and Wales, with special emphasis on storytelling traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Celtic Folklore
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to watch short (roughly 20-minute) asynchronous lecture videos prior to class sessions (other than the first class session).

Synchronous class sessions at the scheduled time will be discussion-focused; it is recommended that students have a working microphone to participate.

There will also be asynchronous participation requirements and opportunities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of contemporary films of Ireland, Scotland and Wales from 1980 to the present, as they relate to representations of Celtic identity and the formation of national cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Celtic Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the most salient aspects of mediaeval manuscript culture. We will study, first, how the parchment for books was folded, pricked, ruled and bound, and second, what scripts were employed in the different codices. We will also examine the various types of books made in the Middle Ages and the challenges they pose to modern scholars.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Mediaeval Book
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: LAT100Y1/LAT102H1; SMC210H1/SMC212H1 or a course in mediaeval history.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Seminar sessions will not be recorded and are strictly synchronous affairs.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of visual arts and architecture as mediums for expressing Christian faith. The course will examine notable developments in Christian history, the proliferation of new forms in the contemporary period, and important local works, such as the Donovan Collection and/or the rich legacy of church architecture in the GTA.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity, Art, and Architecture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: The complex interplay between religious belief, culture, and the emergence of modern physical theory: rise and fall of mechanistic theories, relativity, particle physics and models of the Universe, Big Bang theory and Black Holes, etc.
cmCourseInfo.title: Faith and Physics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course will be run as a seminar. Students will be required to watch pre-recorded lectures asynchronously prior to class. Class time will consist of synchronous, live discussions, which will not be recorded. Students will minimally need a computer with a microphone, though a camera is also desirable. The total time of asynchronous videos and synchronous class discussions will not exceed the alloted two hours of instruction per week.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Oct 30, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the relationship between nationalism and unionism in post-Famine Ireland, with particular emphasis on the debates over Home Rule, the Irish Revolution and Civil War of 1916-23, the effects of partition, and the Troubles in Northern Ireland.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ireland Since the Famine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to watch a one hour pre-recorded lecture before class and then attend a one-hour live seminar-style discussion of weekly readings during the scheduled class time. Office hours will be held via Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced introduction to the Christian intellectual tradition through a study of key figures from several different historical periods and cultural contexts. Selected authors discuss a range of religious, intellectual and social issues, from foundational Christian beliefs to the challenges of modern, post-modern and secular cultures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Christian Thinkers

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

HyFlex
This course will be delivered through synchronous seminar discussions. Students who prefer to join remotely will be given the opportunity to do so via BBcollaborate or Zoom, and should make sure they have all necessary AV equipment at their disposal.

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: St. Michael's College Independent Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.

notes.content:

For "E" indicator courses, please contact Stephanie Taylor at sm.taylor@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

Delivery Instructions

Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the place of music in Christian worship, with a focus on contemporary Eucharist. Examination of the development of liturgico-musical principles and their practical implementation. Topics may include styles and repertoires, singing liturgical texts, hymnody and other forms of congregational singing, choirs and cantors, the use of instruments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music and Liturgy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to advertising and its use in global media. Emphasis is placed on the creative and manipulative character of contemporary advertising, the specialized messaging employed in public life and politics, and the growth of modern agencies for marketing and product promotion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advertising and Media

notes.content:

Office hours and other optional meetings or activities may be occasionally offered in person if possible.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of media’s relation to constructions and representations of identity and power across race, gender and class in private and social spheres. Applies a social justice framework to media technologies and industries as mechanisms for socio-political influence on identity and potential vehicles for restoration and evolution of identity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Identities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously in combination with slides and other course materials. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via webinar are optional (and highly recommended) and held Mondays 1-3pm.  Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Apocalypticism: The End of it all in Medieval Christian Thought

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Sep 11, 2020: Room Change

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: Apocalypticism: The End of it all in Medieval Christian Thought

cmCourseInfo.description: A fourth-year seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Seminar II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course examines Christian speculation on the End of the World from the first century to the later middle ages. It examines topics such as the birth of apocalyptic thought and the development of various medieval traditions about the end. Particular attention will be given to the ways apocalyptic language and symbolism are adapted in response to various historical situations including conflicts and plagues.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed, or held in-person if possible.

cmCourseInfo.description: A fourth-year seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Seminar II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This seminar examines medieval jurisprudence as one of the foundational disciplines in the rise of the Universities and the one of which the newly defined figure of the academic most directly became engaged in the rule and development of all sorts of high medieval and early modern institutions and practices. To register please contact Stephanie Taylor at sm.taylor@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

Delivery Instructions

This course will occur online synchronously.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Celtic Studies I

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 17, 2020: Course Cancelled.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 17, 2020: Course Cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college web site for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Celtic Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course offers students the opportunity to partake in a wide-ranging research project on the significance of Irish-language literature and translation in the modern period. Taking as our focus some of the major texts that have been translated into and out of Irish, we discuss the importance and challenges of minority language dissemination, the strategies employed to maximize cultural impact, and the merit of the texts themselves. Knowledge of Irish language is not required.

Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the history of Irish migration and settlement in Canada with a special emphasis on political, social, economic and religious themes.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Irish in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This seminar will be delivered online through synchronous group discussions as scheduled in the timetable. Students must be equipped with a microphone and a camera to participate in online activities. Discussions will not be recorded.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: A course/seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Literary journalism combines the techniques of prose narrative with factual reporting. In this course, we will closely read examples of literary journalism, taking into consideration all aspects of a story, from how it is composed to how it was reported to how it succeeds or fails as a piece of journalism. The expectations for this course include reading and participating in weekly class discussions of literary journalism articles, as well as reporting and writing your own stories in the literary journalism genre. Selection is based on written application. To apply, please email michael.czobit@utoronto.ca a 250-word statement about your interest in literary journalism and why you would like to enrol in this course. First round of applications are due July 31, 2020. Second round of applications are due August 12, 2020. Late applications will only be considered if there is space left in the course.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed and delivered per the meeting schedule. Students require Zoom and a high-speed Internet connection. Online discussion will take place during the lecture, and participation and attendance to the livestreamed lectures will be noted as part of the final evaluation of the course. Recordings of the lecture will be made available 24-48 hours after the scheduled meeting time; watching the lecture after the livestream will not count toward participation marks.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: A course/seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

From playgrounds, arenas, and tabletops to computers, mobile devices, and video game consoles, games and play are a vibrant and diverse cultural form and a fundamental part of human society. Why do we make and play games? How do games produce experiences, make meaning, and reflect or refract ideology, and what impact do they have on players? Who gets to make, play, and find representation in games and who is left out? What role do games play in the contemporary media ecosystem? This seminar-style class will explore issues around games both analog and digital from a variety of critical perspectives, including history, industry, technology, culture, politics, and aesthetics.

Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access all essential course content online and asynchronously (i.e. watching recordings, completing readings, and making contributions to discussions on their own schedule). Some parts of the course will also optionally be available online synchronously (i.e. livestreamed in real time) Tuesdays 1:00-4:00pm.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: A course/seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course explores a relationship between media and art in the context of historical and contemporary justice movements. In a seminar setting, we open aesthetically mediated entry points into justice by studying various artists’ work and the greater social contexts of intersecting identities within which their art and media are produced. An emphasis is placed on local and community art as activism.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via webinar (or in-person if conditions permit) are optional and are held on Mondays 14:00-16:00. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: A course/seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This advanced seminar expands on the topics learned in SMC228 Book History and Print Culture, providing fourth-year BMS students with an enhanced understanding of printing history, bibliography, and textual scholarship. Contact smc.programs@utoronto.ca to register.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students are expected to attend online lectures and participate in active learning activities and discussions conducted online (valid for participation). Lectures will be also recorded and shared on Quercus for students to review on their own time. Slides and other learning materials, such as weekly required readings and case studies will be posted on Quercus. Students need the ability to use Zoom for all online synchronous sessions, keeping camera and microphone turned on. Keeping camera turned on will allow the class to build a stronger sense of classroom community and help replicate the feel of in-person educational settings, in which students’ faces are always visible. Assignments and term tests will take place on Quercus.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For "E" indicator courses, please contact Stephanie Taylor at sm.taylor@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

Delivery Instructions

Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

cmCourseInfo.description: Middle Welsh, the native Celtic language of medieval Wales, was for centuries the language in which the Welsh celebrated their medieval princes and ancestral heroes, was the medium for the preservation of native British legend and Welsh law, and was the vehicle for the earliest narratives of Arthur. Students will be introduced to reading and translating Middle Welsh, and by the course’s end will have read one complete text of Middle Welsh literature in the original. Students will learn Welsh specifically but will also learn the characteristic linguistic features of a Celtic language. No prior knowledge of Welsh or any other Celtic language is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Welsh

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed and delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of the lectures will be posted on Quercus for review.

courses.name: The Great Irish Famine in an International Context

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
July 27, 2020: Course added.
July 31, 2020: Room added.
August 26, 2020: Course cancelled

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 27, 2020: Course added.</br>August 26, 2020: Course cancelled

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the Great Irish Famine, 1845-1851, in its economic, political, social, demographic and religious dimensions and issues of collective and created memory. By use of manuscript and routinely generated records students will explore mass migration from Ireland to Britain, the Americas, and the Antipodes.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Great Irish Famine in an International Context

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project chosen by the student in consultation with an instructor and approved by the Program Co-ordinator. Arrangements for the choice of topic must be completed by the student before registration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Essay in Celtic Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Based on a professor's research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving hands-on training in research. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Research

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For "E" indicator courses, please contact Stephanie Taylor at sm.taylor@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

Delivery Instructions

LEC0101: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

LEC0201:  The Media Ethics Lab is a research hub that studies the ways that digital media practices and emerging technologies are marked by ethical issues and decisive political, societal and cultural questions. The purposes of this Directed Research Seminar are (a) to provide the students with an understanding of the field of Media Ethics; (b) to actively engage in open research and integrated learning, providing training in research methods and scholarly inquiry; (c) to mentor the capacity of students to be trailblazers in uncovering new ethical perspectives. Group collaboration and discussion will allow students to test-drive ideas, giving the theoretical a practical turn. Students will be constantly encouraged to sketch a picture of current opportunities and challenges for human well-being, as well as put forward innovative solutions for improving digital media environments in the future.

To apply for this course please fill out the application found here  

https://stmikes.utoronto.ca/SMC457H1F-Application-Form/  

Once completed, email it to smc.programs@utoronto.ca. First round of applications are due July 31, 2020. Second round of applications are due August 12, 2020. Late applications will only be considered if there is space left in the course.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: The seminar provides majors in their final year of study with the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects in Christianity and Culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This research seminar invites students to explore connections and tensions between technological innovation and the Christian understanding of death and death-related rituals. Readings and discussions will focus on such themes as extreme unction, burial practices, memorials, and mourning as they relate to technological change, but also engage various means by which humans seek (and have sought historically) to assert their power over death, be it by prolonging life or by denying it to others. Students will be expected to develop a research paper based on a relevant topic of their choosing.

Delivery Instructions

This seminar will be delivered online through synchronous group discussions. Students must be equipped with a microphone and a camera to participate in online activities. Discussions will not be recorded.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: The seminar provides majors in their final year of study with the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects in Christianity and Culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The Second Vatican Council (1962-1964) was the most important religious event in the life of the Catholic Church in the 20th Century. The course will focus on the council and its historical unfolding, the documents it produced, and the impact of both on the church and the world over the last 50 years.

Delivery Instructions

This course will be delivered through synchronous seminar discussions. Students who prefer to join remotely will be given the opportunity to do so via BBcollaborate, and should make sure they have all necessary AV equipment at their disposal.

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: St. Michael's College Independent Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least fifteen full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
